feed.title: NewsTracker: ebola
feed.subtitle: This is a news tracking demo

entry.title: Officials: Alabama home quarantined over possible Ebola case
entry.summary:
Officials say a quarantine is in place at a Birmingham home because of a possible Ebola case.

Khan says the patient recently traveled to a country with Ebola cases, but he didn't identify the country or name the patient.

Khan says the patient didn't have direct contact with anyone known to have Ebola and is considered "low risk" for the disease.

entry.title: CDC head says Sierra Leone in strong place with Ebola
entry.summary: The victim contracted the disease in the capital, traveled to his home village, and was treated for a fever at the local hospital but authorities didn't call the Ebola emergency number.

entry.title: CDC head says Sierra Leone in strong place with Ebola
entry.summary:
Two new cases of Ebola surfaced in Sierra Leone's Northern Tonkolili District after a man died last week.

The district had not had a single case of Ebola in five months.

entry.title: Tekmira suspends work on Ebola drug, will change name
entry.summary:
NEW YORK (AP) " One of the companies that had been studying a potential treatment for the Ebola virus said Monday it will suspend its research on Ebola drugs and change its name.

Tekmira Pharmaceuticals Corp. said last month that an experimental Ebola treatment that it was developing would probably fail in a clinical trial.

Tekmira's experimental drugs were used in at least one patient in 2014 as an Ebola epidemic spread through several West African nations and the search for more effective treatments kicked into high gear.

Tekmira said it will suspend work on its drug TKM-Ebola and is re-evaluating its development contract with the U.S. Department of Defense.

entry.title: Liberia says 4 remaining Ebola patients have recovered
entry.summary: Liberia cannot be declared Ebola transmission-free again until it goes 42 days - twice the maximum incubation period - without any new cases.

entry.title: Liberia says 4 remaining Ebola patients have recovered
entry.summary:
MONROVIA, Liberia -- The four remaining patients infected during Liberia's recent string of Ebola cases have recovered, meaning there are currently no confirmed cases in the country though more than 100 people are still under surveillance, a health official said Friday.

Ebola killed more than 4,800 people in Liberia before the country was declared Ebola transmission-free on May 9.

entry.title: Liberia confirms 2nd Ebola death in resurgent outbreak
entry.summary: Deputy Health Minister and head of the Ebola response, Tolbert Nyenswah, told The Associated Press the woman in her early 20s who died on July 12 was linked to the 17-year-old boy who died last month.

entry.title: Liberia confirms 2nd Ebola death in resurgent outbreak
entry.summary: Samples taken from the 17-year-old boy who died from Ebola in Liberia on June 28 shows the virus is genetically similar to viruses that infected many people in the same area more than six months ago, the World Health Organization has said.

entry.title: Liberia confirms 2nd Ebola death in resurgent outbreak
entry.summary: MONROVIA, Liberia (AP) - Liberia's health minister says that a second person has died from Ebola in the latest resurgence of the deadly disease.

entry.title: Liberia confirms 2nd Ebola death in resurgent outbreak
entry.summary: Liberia lost more than 4,800 lives to Ebola before it contained transmission in May. These are the first known cases since then.

entry.title: Liberia confirms new Ebola case as outbreak spreads
Inhalable Vaccine Developed for Ebola
UN: Africas Ebola outbreak has not run its course
entry.summary: The Ebola outbreak has galvanized a global response.

entry.title: Africaâ€™s Ebola outbreak has not run its course
entry.summary: Africa's Ebola epidemic has not run its course and around 30 people are still getting infected each week, the United Nations' special envoy for the disease said on Monday.

entry.title: UN envoy says Africa's Ebola outbreak not yet run its course
entry.summary: The worst recorded outbreak of Ebola has already killed more than 11,200 people across West Africa.

entry.title: Tests show Ebola in Liberia linked to virus found months ago
entry.summary:
Five new cases of Ebola have been confirmed in the town of Nedowein, including the teen who died June 28.

The virus spreads through direct contact with an Ebola patient's blood or other body fluids like urine, saliva, semen and sweat.

entry.title: Mystery of new Liberian Ebola case raised by test
entry.summary:
The home of Abraham Memaigar, one of two persons confirmed to be infected with Ebola, in Nedowein, Liberia.

Dakar/Geneva: Tests on the Ebola virus that claimed Liberia's first victim since it was declared Ebola-free in May showed it was closely related to an earlier Liberian strain, the World Health Organisation and a health official said on Friday.

Liberia's first Ebola case in nearly two months was reported on June 30 when the body of a 17-year-old boy, Abraham Memaigar, tested positive for the virus in Margibi County.

Ebola is thought to be able to survive no more than 21 days in most body fluids, such as blood and vomit, but is known to persist in semen and in some soft tissues, such as the eye, for months after recovery.

entry.title: World Health Organisation slammed on Ebola response
entry.summary:
Liberia, one of the countries hardest hit by the Ebola epidemic, reports its first new case since being declared free of the lethal virus seven weeks ago.

London: Experts have recommended urgent, root-and-branch changes to the World Health Organisation after an inadequate response to West Africa's vast and deadly Ebola outbreak.

The UN agency "does not currently possess the capacity or organisational culture to deliver a full emergency public health response", a panel of independent experts said in a report on the WHO's handling of the Ebola crisis.

The house where the 17-year-old lived before he died of Ebola.

It said that WHO leaders should have declared the Ebola outbreak a public health emergency much sooner than they did, and that the delay stemmed in part from not wanting to challenge governments worried about negative economic and trade consequences.

Ebola health workers spray disinfectant on an ambulance that was used to transport two people suspected of having the Ebola virus on the outskirts of Monrovia earlier this month.

Health workers take a blood specimen from a child to test for the Ebola virus in the district where the 17-year-old had lived.

entry.title: Panel: Politics among reasons for botched UN Ebola response
entry.summary:
FILE - In this Wednesday, March 11, 2015 file photo, health workers carry a body of a person that they suspected died form the Ebola virus at a new graveyard on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia.

A panel commissioned by the World Health Organization to assess its bungled response to the world's biggest Ebola outbreak said the crisis exposed the agency's "organizational failings" and called for WHO to be held accountable.

In its final report issued on Tuesday, July 7, 2015 the panel said WHO's sluggish efforts to contain Ebola were partly explained by "a hope that the crisis could be managed by good diplomacy."

entry.title: Panel: Politics among reasons for botched UN Ebola response
entry.summary:
WHO did not declare a global emergency for Ebola until August 8, when nearly 1,000 people had died from the disease.

More than 11,000 people are estimated to have been killed by Ebola, the vast majority in three West African nations of Guinea, Sierra Leone and Liberia, since the outbreak was first identified in March 2014 in Guinea.

But Liu said it was still disconcerting that the panel and other such groups were laying out the world's lessons learned as Ebola was still claiming more victims every week.
